headline: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
companyname: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc.
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Interpublic Group Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] This conference is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time. I would like to introduce Mr. Jerry Les
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the Interpublic Group Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] This conference is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time. I would like to introduce Mr. Jerry Leshne, Senior Vice President of Investor Relations. Sir, you may begin.

headline: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
companyname: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc.
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Thank you for joining us. We have posted our earnings release and our slide presentation on our website, interpublic.com.  This morning, we are joined by Michael Roth and Frank Mergenthaler. We will begin with prepared remarks to be followed
componenttext:
Good morning. Thank you for joining us. We have posted our earnings release and our slide presentation on our website, interpublic.com.  This morning, we are joined by Michael Roth and Frank Mergenthaler. We will begin with prepared remarks to be followed by Q&A. We plan to conclude before market open at 9:30 Eastern. 
During this call, we will refer to forward-looking statements about our company. These are subject to the uncertainties in the cautionary statement that are included in our earnings release and the slide presentation and further detailed in our 10-Q and other filings with the SEC. We will also refer to certain non-GAAP measures. We believe that these measures provide useful supplemental data that, while not a substitute for GAAP measures, allow for greater transparency in the review of our financial and operational performance. 
At this point, it is my pleasure to turn things over to Michael Roth.

headline: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
companyname: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc.
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jerry, and thank you for joining us this morning as we review our results for the third quarter and first 9 months of 2016.  I'll start out by covering highlights of our performance. Frank will then provide additional detail, and I'll conclude
componenttext:
Thank you, Jerry, and thank you for joining us this morning as we review our results for the third quarter and first 9 months of 2016.  I'll start out by covering highlights of our performance. Frank will then provide additional detail, and I'll conclude with an update on our agencies and the tone of our business, to be followed by our Q&A. 
We're pleased to report another quarter of solid revenue and profit increases. Our third quarter organic revenue growth was 4.3% on top of a very strong 7.1% in Q3 '15. Acquisitions had a positive impact of 40 basis points while FX was a negative 1.7%. As a result, total revenue growth was 3%. 
We continue to see positive momentum in the quarter from a broad range of our creative, marketing services and media offerings. Our digital capabilities also continue to be very significant drivers of growth for us. 
As you remember, as of some years ago, we committed to organically building digital talent and expertise within every agency across our organization so as to effectively migrate to new competencies and serve the evolving needs of marketers. Our results demonstrate that this strategy continues to pay off. 
In terms of geography, we grew organically in every world region, with the exception of Asia Pac. Our international organic growth was 8.1%, driven by Continental Europe, the U.K. and LatAm. U.S. organic growth was 1.8% for the 3 months against extremely strong comparables in the quarter for 2 consecutive years. 
Globally, we continue to see growth from nearly every client industry and were led by the tech and telecom and food and beverage sectors. 
Turning to Q3 operating expenses and margin. Operating expenses increased 2.5% compared with reported revenue growth of 3%. And as a result, operating margin expanded 50 basis points from last year's third quarter to 10.8%, reflecting leverage on our salaries and related expenses. 
For the first 9 months of the year, organic growth was 4.8%. This was very well balanced with 4.8% growth in the U.S. and 4.9% internationally. It's worth noting that the charge in pass-through services added 90 basis points to our organic growth in the quarter and added 10 basis points through 9 months. 
Operating profit year-to-date is up 9%, and operating margin in the same period expanded 40 basis points, reaching the level of 11.7% for the trailing 12-month period, which is the highest level our company has achieved in well over a decade. 
Adjusted diluted EPS was $0.64 this year through the third quarter compared to $0.55 in 2015, an increase of 16%. 
Turning to our update on share repurchases. During Q3, we used $81 million to repurchase 3.5 million shares. Year-to-date, we've utilized approximately $193 million repurchasing 8.5 million common shares. Since instituting our return of capital programs in 2011, we've returned $2.9 billion to shareholders in dividends and share repurchases as well as reduced our diluted share count by 27%.  At the end of the third quarter, we had $265 million remaining on our current authorization. 
Overall, our performance continues to underscore the strong competitive position of our agencies around the world and across the full spectrum of advertising and marketing disciplines. The strength and growth of digital activity is also notable. We continue to manage expenses effectively in order to deliver on our margin objectives, which has been a key priority for us. As we head into our always important fourth quarter, economic and political conditions continue to present macro uncertainties.  Nonetheless, the overall tone of business remains solid. 
We've also posted another good year in the new business front. And while the tailwinds from recent wins were relatively slight this past quarter due to timing, we expect the impact to be more evident in Q4. 
We have previously increased our full year 2016 organic growth target to the high end of 3% to 4% range that we shared with you coming into the year. In light of the strength of our offerings and our strong organic revenue performance through 9 months, we believe it's appropriate to raise our organic growth target to a range of 4% to 5%. 
Given the high levels of profit contributions, we have historically seen on our growth in the fourth quarter, we continue to feel that we remain well positioned to achieve 50 basis points or more of operating margin expansion for the full year '16. 
At this stage, I'll turn things over to Frank for the additional detail of our results and join you after his remarks for an update on our operating units to be followed by Q&A. Frank?

headline: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
companyname: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc.
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Michael. Good morning. As a reminder, I'll be referring to the slide presentation that accompanies our webcast. On Slide 2, you'll see an overview of results, a number of which Michael has touched upon. Organic revenue growth was 4.3% in the
componenttext:
Thank you, Michael. Good morning. As a reminder, I'll be referring to the slide presentation that accompanies our webcast. 
On Slide 2, you'll see an overview of results, a number of which Michael has touched upon. Organic revenue growth was 4.3% in the quarter and 4.8% for the first 9 months. Q3 operating profit was $207 million with operating margin of 10.8%, an increase of 50 basis points from a year ago. For the 9 months, operating margin expanded 40 basis points and operating profit grew 9%.  Third quarter diluted EPS was $0.32 a share and was $0.31 adjusted for certain below-the-line items in the quarter. This compares to last year's diluted EPS of $0.27.  For the 9 months, adjusted diluted EPS was $0.64 this year compared with $0.55 in 2015, an increase of 16%. Average fully diluted shares in Q3 decreased by 1.8% from last year due to our share repurchase program. 
Turning to Slide 3 you'll see our P&L for the quarter. I'll cover revenue and operating expenses in detail in the slides that follow. Here, it is worth noting that our adjusted effective tax rate in the quarter was 33%, which compares favorably to our adjusted effective tax rate in Q3 '15 of 36%.  As you have seen in the past, we have volatility in our tax rate from quarter-to-quarter. We continue to expect that our full year 2016 adjusted effective rate will be at the lower end of 37% to 39% range that we indicated earlier in the year. 
Slide 4 has more detail on our average -- on our revenue growth. Revenue was $1.92 billion in the quarter, an increase of 3%. Compared to Q3 '15, the impact of the change in currency exchange rates was a negative 1.7%.  Our net acquisitions added 40 basis points to revenue. The resulting organic revenue increase was 4.3%. 
It's worth noting that net increase in pass-through revenue in the quarter mainly in our events business in the U.K. benefited organic growth by 90 basis points. For the 9 months, our change in pass-through revenue only increased organic revenue by 10 basis points. 
As you can see on the bottom half of the slide, our Integrated Agency Networks, the organic increase was 3%. This was led by strong growth at McCann, R/GA and Huge. IAN's organic growth over the first 9 months was 4.7%. 
At our CMG segment, a marketing services specialist, organic growth was 9.4%. We again had strong performance at Weber Shandwick as well as our events business, Jack Morton, and our sports marketing at Octagon. Organic growth was 5.6% at CMG, excluding the impact of higher pass-through revenues.  For the 9 months, organic growth was 5.3%. 
Moving on to Slide 5, revenue by region. In the U.S., Q3 organic growth was 1.8% on top of 7.1% in Q3 '15 and 7.9% in 2014. Excluding the impact of lower pass-through revenue, organic revenue growth was 2%.  It is worth noting that acquisitions in the U.S. added another 60 basis points in the quarter. Leading client sectors were food and beverage and tech and telecom as well as our other sector of diverse clients.  Slower U.S. growth compared to the first half of this year was due to a less robust tailwind from the timing of account wins and to a particularly strong comp in the health care sector. 
In the U.K., organic growth was 16.4% and was 4.8% excluding the positive impact from higher pass-through revenues at our event specialist, Jack Morton. With continuing strong performance from McCann, R/GA and Octagon as well as Jack Morton, U.K. acquisitions add 3.9% to our growth in the quarter. By client sector, we were led by tech and telecom and health care.  It's worth noting that our U.K. operators are not citing a specific impact on client spending related to Brexit. 
Turning to Continental Europe. Organic growth was 8.3% in the quarter, a strong result driven by new business wins in the region. We had notable increases in the retail and food and beverage sectors led by Mediabrands and McCann in Germany and Spain among our largest markets. 
In Asia Pac, our organic decrease in Q3 was 1.4%. This comes on top of 7.2% growth a year ago. In our largest regional markets, we had high single-digit growth in India, while revenues decreased in Australia and China. For the 9 months, our organic revenue decreased the [ph] region was 80 basis points. 
In LatAm, Q3 organic growth was a strong 17.8% on top of 14.4% growth a year ago with increases in all of our largest national markets, including Brazil, Argentina, Colombia and Mexico. Growth was driven by higher spend by existing clients and by new client wins.  We had notably strong performances from McCann, R/GA, Huge, Mediabrands, Octagon and FutureBrand. For the 9 months, organic growth was 15.4%. 
In our Other Markets group, organic growth continued to be strong in Q3 at 5.6%, driven by new business wins and by performance in Canada led by Mediabrands and Huge. Organic growth was 6.7% for the 9 months. 
On Slide 6, we chart the longer view of our organic revenue change on a trailing 12-month basis. The most recent data point is 4.9%. 
Moving on to Slide 7, our operating expenses. In the third quarter, total operating expenses increased 2.5% from a year ago compared with our reported revenue growth of 3%. FX reduced our percentage of operating margin by 10 basis points in the quarter compared to last year but was neutral for the margin for 9 months. 
Underneath our margin improvement of 50 basis points in Q3, the ratio of salaries and related expenses to revenue was 63.9% this year compared with 64.4% a year ago. The improvement was driven by year-on-year operating leverage on 2 categories: Our expense for incentives and for our category of other salaries and related expenses. This was partially offset by increased base payroll and temporary health as a percentage of revenue. 
Our total headcount at quarter end was approximately 50,400, an increase of 3.4% year-on-year. This reflects both organic hiring and acquisitions in support of our growth in areas such as digital, creative, media and PR. 
Turning to office and general expenses on the lower half of the slide. O&G expense was 25.3% of Q3 revenue compared with the same level a year ago. We leveraged our expenses for travel, supplies and telecom as well as for professional fees. That was offset by increased pass-through expenses as a percentage of revenue in our other O&G category.  The net result was operating margin expansion of 50 basis points in the quarter and 40 basis points for the first 9 months. 
Slide 8 depicts our operating margin history on a trailing 12-month basis. The most recent data point is 11.7%, which is an improvement of 60 basis points from a year ago. 
Slide 9 is provided for clarity on our EPS adjustment in the quarter. We had a below-the-line gain of $3.9 million in other income, primarily due to the sale of a small nonstrategic business outside the U.S. Net benefit to our diluted EPS was $0.01. As you can see, the impact of a new accounting standard for share-based compensation was de minimis in the quarter. Adjusted diluted EPS was $0.31. 
Moving on to Slide 10, the current portion of our balance sheet. We ended the quarter with $895 million in cash and short term marketable securities, which is comparable to the level last year. The comparison to December 31 reflects that our cash level is seasonal and tends to peek at year-end. 
Slide 11 is our third quarter cash flow. Cash provided by operations was $520 million compared with $282 million a year ago. The comparison reflects increased cash generated from working capital this year, $318 million compared to $155 million a year ago.  As we have pointed out previously, working capital can be volatile quarter by quarter. 
Investing activities used $65 million mainly for CapEx. Financing activities used $234 million chiefly for share repurchases and our common stock dividend as well as to decrease short-term borrowings.  Our net increase in cash and marketable securities for the quarter was $219 million. 
On Slide 12, we show our debt deleveraging from a peak of $2.33 billion in 2007 to $1.74 billion at the most recent quarter end. 
In summary, on Slide 13, through 9 months, we have achieved 4.8% organic growth and 40 basis points of margin expansion, which represents very solid progress to our objectives for the full year. 
We are seeing growth in areas where we have focused on investment in both people and acquisitions. Our operators are focused on the appropriate cost disciplines and margin expansion, and our balance sheet is an important area that we can continue to deploy for value going forward. 
With that, let me turn it back to Michael.

headline: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
companyname: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc.
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Frank. Well as you can see, through the first 9 months of 2016, we reported solid results in terms of both organic revenue growth and margin progress. As I've mentioned, contributions to our positive results came from across the portfolio. Ther
componenttext:
Thank you, Frank. Well as you can see, through the first 9 months of 2016, we reported solid results in terms of both organic revenue growth and margin progress. As I've mentioned, contributions to our positive results came from across the portfolio. There was very good balance among our agencies, geographic regions and most of all, client categories. 
Behind this strength are 2 very key strategic decisions that we took some time ago. The first was to invest in talent and foster a culture that makes us a top choice for talent in every marketing discipline and capability. Given how important compelling content is for any media, entertainment or communications company in the current environment, having the most outstanding creative strategic and digital talent has never been more vital for success, and we are well positioned in this regard. 
Now the talent priority that has long been key for us is our commitment to diversity and inclusion as a driver of business performance. An environment that encourages respect and trust is key to a creative business like ours, and a competitive advantage comes with having a variety of perspectives and beliefs when solving our clients' business challenges. We have reinforced this focus through a comprehensive set of award-winning programs, and we ensure accountability by tying executive compensation directly to the ability of our leaders to achieve diversity objectives.  While Interpublic has made a great deal of progress and we take pride in that, as an industry, we still have a ways to go in this journey. 
The second major strategic decision is our approach to digital. Unlike some of our competitors, IPG's digital capabilities have been largely grown organically and are embedded within every one of our agencies. This investment in people with new skill sets in developing new products and services and in incubating new technology has allowed us to stay highly relevant in today's digital world. 
We want to be the first place clients turn to for help and guidance as they seek to navigate the complexity of the media and marketing landscape. We know that there are some questions out there about what technology convergence will mean to our industry going forward. We may all be facing new kinds of competitors. As more comes, IT and consulting come together. However, it's worth noting that to date, the emergence of technology-enabled marketing has created meaningful opportunity for the agency holding companies. This has definitely been the case for IPG given our skill set focused on digital, our media-agnostic view of channel allocation and a long-standing commitment to open architecture, where we've been an industry leader with this approach to delivering the best customized talent and solutions that can provide the integration of marketing functions our clients are increasingly asking for. 
What is not commonly understood is how much resource IPG already has in place across the group when it comes to data expertise, data analytics and proprietary tools that we can bring to bear in order to create accountable marketing campaigns that drive marketplace results. Data and analytics is an area we will continue to focus and invest behind so as to ensure that we can create even more targeted, dynamic and effective work on behalf of our clients. 
Moving on to operational results. It's clear that during the quarter and for the year-to-date, in addition to solid growth, we've continued to be very disciplined in terms of cost management. We remain focused on converting at the appropriate levels to deliver our margin improvement target for the year. 
We also remain committed to the kind of robust capital return programs that we've put in place in recent years, which have been driving significant shareholder value creation. 
At the agency level, McCann Worldgroup's performance in the quarter was strong. Their creative product continue to earn high levels of industry recognition, and they're growing well in a number of their major clients.  Notable wins came from Reckitt Benckiser and Chick-fil-A as well as Qualcomm this past October.  We're seeing a high degree of collaboration among McCann advertising, MRM, Momentum and their strong health care offerings. 
Mediabrands, once again, made significant contributions to our profitability. UM has been building out its teams to deliver for recent global wins. Leading-edge capabilities like Cadreon and Ansible are also being introduced into a range of new international markets, and we added to the reprised SEO offering with an attractive acquisition based out of the U.K. that will serve as a regional center of excellence.  
Mediabrands also recently recruited strong new leaders for EMEA and Asia Pac regions.  Furthermore, in the quarter, they retained BMW North America and extended Coca-Cola in the Middle East. 
As mentioned last quarter, we have a long-standing record of transparency in our dealings with marketers and media vendors. We are proud of the role we play as wholly objective and media-agnostic advisers to our clients. 
At CMG, we saw a continued outstanding work out of Weber Shandwick. Some of you will have previously heard of point [ph] out that is the full range of Weber's digital capabilities from strategy through analytics all the way to content creation, where in a standalone company, it would be one of the largest social media agencies in the world. 
Octagon and Jack Morton were also strong performers in the quarter. 
MullenLowe continue to make headway in terms of integrating the network and promoted new leaders for its New York and London agencies, both our executives who came to the company through the acquisition of digital agency, Profero, which made important contributions to Q3 performance. MullenLowe also benefited from its bundled media offering, Mediahub, which continues to partner closely with Mediabrands as it did in the recent global win of Western Union. 
FCB is producing visible and successful new advertising work for clients, including AB InBev and a number of Chrysler brands, with work for new global client, Clorox, soon to follow.  The agency further bolstered its leadership with a significant creative hire. She will lead the creative group in the flagship Chicago office. 
FCB RED, the agency shopper marketing unit, is a market leader as our operations in a number of key emerging markets, including India, Brazil and South Africa. 
As you know, we have a range of full services domestic agencies, including Deutsche, Hill Holliday and the Martin Agency and Carmichael Lynch, which can serve clients independently or partner with other IPG units in the customized integrated offerings that we refer to as open architecture.  As mentioned earlier, this is a concept that we've been working to refine for some time. It has fueled many of our largest wins in recent years, including, recently, Harley-Davidson this quarter. And it's something you're now hearing more about from a number of our competitors. 
An additional highlight in the quarter was the performance of R/GA and Huge. These are among the industry's best digital networks. The strategic work they do for clients on digital transformation rival that of any consultancy. And the range of services they provide from UX and design to strategy, digital storytelling, data visualization and more is unrivaled in our industry.  Starting from a single agency in New York, both R/GA and Huge are evolving into powerful multi-office networks. In the case of R/GA, there are now 14 locations on 4 continents.  During the quarter, they posted major wins with Siemens and Mercedes-Benz. 
Huge has grown to 7 office -- U.S. offices and an equal number internationally, working with major clients, including Google, HBO and Under Armour. 
Looking forward, as mentioned in my opening remarks, the tone of the business remains solid. The new business pipeline is strong overall, and we are new -- [ph] business positive for year-to-date.  As indicated previously, tailwinds from recent wins with will be more prevalent in Q4 than they were in Q3, which we are sharing with you today. 
Investments in talent, supplemented by a measured and strategic approach to acquisitions, should ensure that the level of professional offerings remain highly competitive. And that's vital for us to capitalize on the level of complexity and even confusion that exists in today's marketing landscape. Despite the macro uncertainty that's out there due to political and economic factors at play around the globe, we're highly focused on delivering against our top and bottom line targets for the year. 
As stated at the outset, in light of the strength of our offerings and our strong organic revenue performance through 9 months, we believe it's appropriate to raise our full year organic growth target from our previous 3% to 4% to a range of 4% to 5%. 
Given the high levels of profit contributions we have historically seen in our growth in the fourth quarter, we also believe that we remain well positioned to achieve our target of expanding 2016 operating margin by 50 basis points or more. 
Combined with the strength of our balance sheet and our proven commitment to capital return, which has been a source of significant value creation, this will allow us to further enhance shareholder value. 
As always, we thank you for your support. We're intent on closing out the year strongly, and we look forward to posting you on our results at our next call. 
With that, let's open it up for questions.

headline: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
companyname: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc.
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Alexia Quadrani from JPMorgan.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Alexia Quadrani from JPMorgan.

headline: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
companyname: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc.
componenttextpreview: Just digging in a little bit further on the U.S. organic growth in the quarter. I think you -- Frank, I think you highlighted a very difficult comp on the health care side and then obviously, a little bit less tailwinds I think you [ph] both had in terms
componenttext: Just digging in a little bit further on the U.S. organic growth in the quarter. I think you -- Frank, I think you highlighted a very difficult comp on the health care side and then obviously, a little bit less tailwinds I think you [ph] both had in terms of new business in the quarter. Given the tailwinds are supposed to pick up in Q4, is there an unusually difficult [ph] comp in Q4? I guess, how should we think about sort of the underlying growth rate of the U.S.? I pushed on it because a couple of your peers also highlighted weakness in the U.S. organic growth. And when they reported earlier this week, some cited some election noise. I guess, any more color you can give on the underlying trend of the U.S. market will be great.

headline: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
companyname: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc.
componenttextpreview: Yes, thank you. Let me just say, for the 9 months, our growth was 4.8% in the U.S., which still is a solid performance given where -- our forecast for the full year and what the industry is saying in terms of the macro growth of our industry. And yes, you
componenttext: Yes, thank you. Let me just say, for the 9 months, our growth was 4.8% in the U.S., which still is a solid performance given where -- our forecast for the full year and what the industry is saying in terms of the macro growth of our industry. And yes, you pointed out correctly that in the third quarter, we're a little bit light in the U.S. compared to what we've been delivering. We've grown organically 15% in the last 2 years in the U.S. And obviously, as we grow, it gets a little bit more difficult. That said, the tailwinds that we refer to, we've indicated were light in the third quarter, the coming in the fourth quarter. I can't say -- again, it's a function of the fourth quarter. A lot of our revenue comes in, a lot of our operating margin comes in in the fourth quarter. I'd like to tell you that all of that tailwind comes in the U.S. and we're back to levels of organic growth that you've seen, but I can't say that. We do think there will be improvement in the U.S. in the fourth quarter, but I think the health care item that Frank pointed out, we had a tough comp in that health care side, and we did have a little bit slowing down, in particular, in one of our agencies in terms of health care, and that contributed to it. But again, I'm very comfortable with a performance we have in the U.S. It continues to be a key driver for us going forward. What I like about our U.S. performance for the year is that it's across all of our agencies. We see MullenLowe, we see McCann, Mediabrands, CMG, our independent agencies, all of our agencies are strong in the U.S. and I believe, we will continue to see improvement in those markets.

headline: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
companyname: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc.
componenttextpreview: And then just to follow up if I can on the very strong growth you saw in Europe in the quarter. The pass-through revenues, I think you highlighted health a bit. Was that purely in the U.K? Was there any pass-through a year ago in the U.K. in the same peri
componenttext: And then just to follow up if I can on the very strong growth you saw in Europe in the quarter. The pass-through revenues, I think you highlighted health a bit. Was that purely in the U.K? Was there any pass-through a year ago in the U.K. in the same period that were comping? And then on the Continental Europe, that's a very impressive growth there. It sounds like it sort of just generally improvement from what you've been doing and some new business or there is something onetime in there we should look into?

headline: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
companyname: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc.
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me focus in the U.K. I don't believe we have -- it was a one big event and we saw that at Jack Morton. But other than that, we still had a solid performance in the U.K. of 4.8% growth in the U.K., I think that's the right number, right? So we're
componenttext:
Yes, let me focus in the U.K. I don't believe we have -- it was a one big event and we saw that at Jack Morton. But other than that, we still had a solid performance in the U.K. of 4.8% growth in the U.K., I think that's the right number, right? So we're still pleased. We continue to have strong performance across the CMG portfolio as well as our agencies in the U.K. So we're pleased. R/GA, in particular, is very strong in the U.K. Management there and the offerings we see in R/GA is particularly strong and growing nicely. So we don't -- and as far as Brexit goes, as we said, we haven't seen any impact on Brexit yet. Obviously, sometime down the road, we'll see some impact, but we haven't seen it.
Continental Europe is a different story in that as you know, it's 8% of our revenue, at least for the 9 months. And new wins and client spend in that particular region has a nice affect, which is what you're seeing in this quarter with the results for Continental Europe. We said for out of full year basis, we've always said, we see 1% up or 1% down, it's encouraging that we seeing that kind of improvement. We saw good flow through in terms of new business at McCann as well as Mediabrands as they on-boarded some new client wins that we have in those markets, particularly in Germany and Spain. So we're excited to see some improvement in the Continental Europe again, we're not raising a flag of total victory in Continental Europe. They still have many challenges, but our client mix, if you will, is producing those kind of results.

headline: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
companyname: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc.

componenttext: Our next question is from Mr. Ben Swinburne from Morgan Stanley.

headline: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
companyname: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc.
componenttextpreview: Last quarter, you guys talked about some revenue I think in the U.S. that had slipped a bit. I think you had indicated back half. I was wondering if you could revisit that and talk whether that is -- continue to be out there or if that showed up in the th
componenttext: Last quarter, you guys talked about some revenue I think in the U.S. that had slipped a bit. I think you had indicated back half. I was wondering if you could revisit that and talk whether that is -- continue to be out there or if that showed up in the third quarter. Any color around timing and sizing? And then Frank, I was just wondering if you can help us. On the pass-through impact and margins, would you have gotten some leverage in all other O&G if not for the 90 basis points of pass-through? Just some color on some underlying margin trajectory would be great, too.

headline: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
companyname: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc.
componenttextpreview: Well, let me just quickly, on that pass-through, in terms of margin, the affect in the margin was only 10 basis points this quarter, if you will. And for the full year, we expect that to be neutral. It will stand out, if you will. And I think what you're
componenttext: Well, let me just quickly, on that pass-through, in terms of margin, the affect in the margin was only 10 basis points this quarter, if you will. And for the full year, we expect that to be neutral. It will stand out, if you will. And I think what you're referring to last year in the fourth quarter, we did have an impact on margin that was higher than that, but we don't see that in the fourth quarter. As far as the timing goes, we did see, as we said, the tailwinds were not as robust in the third quarter, and we will see that tailwind coming in, in the fourth quarter. But it's not all U.S. So I wish I could tell you that all of it was U.S. and we did back up in terms of the higher numbers for U.S. But the good news is, we do have the tailwinds, they will hit us in the fourth quarter, but I couldn't tell you that the majority of that pass-through is coming in the U.S., and that's how I responded before to the question.

headline: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
companyname: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc.
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then as a follow-up. Michael, I'm sure you've listened to [indiscernible], the earning commentary from your competitors this week. It seems to be very focused on the U.S. election as we are, I'm sure, enjoying in this process. I'm just wonderi
componenttext: Got it. And then as a follow-up. Michael, I'm sure you've listened to [indiscernible], the earning commentary from your competitors this week. It seems to be very focused on the U.S. election as we are, I'm sure, enjoying in this process. I'm just wondering, you didn't bring it up at all in your prepared remarks, you seemed quite confident in the tone. Any sense from even any media sector-specific like health care, where the election outcome poses incremental challenge to spending? Any thoughts there at all?

headline: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
companyname: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc.
componenttextpreview: No, we haven't seen an impact. First of all, from the business perspective, we don't play in that arena so it didn't affect us. It did affect us in the media side because we have to place local media and obviously, that was being crowded out by elections,
componenttext: No, we haven't seen an impact. First of all, from the business perspective, we don't play in that arena so it didn't affect us. It did affect us in the media side because we have to place local media and obviously, that was being crowded out by elections, so we have to find new ways of reaching consumers in those markets were more efficient. That helps us a bit, okay, in terms of consulting with our clients. But we haven't seen a big political impact. As far as the tone of business, particularly in Europe, I think they're nervous. But I can't particularly point to a particular client hold back as a result, but I think they're watching us very carefully. And frankly, they should be concerned about it. But I think we'll be okay and our clients are very sophisticated in terms of where they allocate their dollars and the tones of business, and we are right with them focusing on that. But I have not seen as much of a dramatic impact that some of our competitors said on the calls. And I think the U.S. issue that showed up frankly, so far in all 3 of our results indicate that a lot of this is client and sector-specific, and we're seeing that. But I continue to believe that 61% of our business is in the U.S, and I like that positioning right now given the tone of the business.

headline: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016

componenttext: The next question is from Mr. Peter Stabler from Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
companyname: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc.
componenttextpreview: So a couple, if I could. The first one on the ANA and transparency. Michael, you've talked about your position in IPG, you're not buying digital media as a principal. Wondering, do you think the ANA comments and some disclosures from one of your competito
componenttext: So a couple, if I could. The first one on the ANA and transparency. Michael, you've talked about your position in IPG, you're not buying digital media as a principal. Wondering, do you think the ANA comments and some disclosures from one of your competitors around digital buying overseas, do you think it's resulting in a new sort of attitude shift in the market towards transparent digital buying and whether you guys could be a beneficiary of that? And then I've got a quick follow up.

headline: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
companyname: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc.
componenttextpreview: Yes, I've said this before and if I didn't believe this, we would change our strategy. Our conversations with our clients and the pictures that we've been involved in, although I can't say specifically the reason that we either win business or not, our tr
componenttext: Yes, I've said this before and if I didn't believe this, we would change our strategy. Our conversations with our clients and the pictures that we've been involved in, although I can't say specifically the reason that we either win business or not, our transparency reputation and the fact that we are media agnostic makes a difference with our clients. And the more you see and press about questions on that, the more it becomes relevant in our conversations. And yes, I do believe it enhances our opportunity to expand our media offerings. And I think, as I said, I think rather than us changing to what our competitors are doing, I think we're going to see a slowing down of that on the other side because I think clients deserve the transparency that we give them, and I think they're entitled to realize and know where their profitability is coming at their expense. And I think that's the right way to approach this environment.

headline: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
companyname: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc.
componenttextpreview: Great. And then quickly back to the region, Latin America, you cited broad strength across a number of countries. You didn't call out the Olympics. I'm wondering, does that suggest that you're confident that some of the strength could have continued just
componenttext: Great. And then quickly back to the region, Latin America, you cited broad strength across a number of countries. You didn't call out the Olympics. I'm wondering, does that suggest that you're confident that some of the strength could have continued just some comments and that would be great.

headline: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
companyname: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc.
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's a great question, Peter. Yes, we had said before, we didn't see a big impact on the Olympics. We did have some obviously our marketing services businesses are Octagon and Jack Morton obviously had some events in the Olympics, which affected ou
componenttext: Yes, that's a great question, Peter. Yes, we had said before, we didn't see a big impact on the Olympics. We did have some obviously our marketing services businesses are Octagon and Jack Morton obviously had some events in the Olympics, which affected our results, not materially. But no, actually that's real growth. And you were kind in your question. Yes, we did onboard some new clients in Latin America in terms of LatAm Airways and Bradesco, and we see some client spend increasing there. So that's what you're seeing the reason for our growth in Brazil, so it's client specific, it's onboarding. And frankly, what I like about it is across the regions in Latin America, it's not all Brazil. We're seeing strength in other market. We're seeing our digital offerings do very well in Latin America. R/GA and Huge are doing very well down there because the digital environment is right for growth. And frankly, we use those markets for production facilities given the talent base that we have in Latin America and the effectiveness that we've been able to utilize that talent on a worldwide basis. R/GA, in particular, as well as Huge, use that as a base to service global clients, if you will, in the connected world as Greenberg. And we're seeing that come to fruition using those resources in Latin America.

headline: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016

componenttext: First question I just maybe wanted to zero in a bit more on some of the U.S. commentary if possible. It looks like probably for 2017, you have a slightly easier comp than what you have on 2016, but you also talked about maybe some of the new business being outside of the U.S. So should we sort of the medium term think about an acceleration organically in the U.S. business? Or is it just a bit more of a complex picture than that in that new business acceleration is more global?

headline: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
companyname: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc.
componenttextpreview: While I appreciate your question. Right now, we're really focused on getting through 2016. We haven't started our 2017 forecasting models yet in terms of our business reviews. I think the only way to look at this is that 61% of our business continues to b
componenttext: While I appreciate your question. Right now, we're really focused on getting through 2016. We haven't started our 2017 forecasting models yet in terms of our business reviews. I think the only way to look at this is that 61% of our business continues to be in the U.S. The tone of the business is solid. If you look at MAGNA in terms of their forecast of U.S. advertising, roughly 4% is the growth expectations. I think if you use that as a guideline, we should be, plus or minus that, and we'll talk to you more about 2017 when we give you our full results for 2016.

headline: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
companyname: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc.
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's fair. And then maybe if we think about pace of reviews coming up, both for Q4 and what you're seeing in the RFP pipeline for next year. And I guess, kind of question goes back to what you've talked about with your media agnostic strategy as w
componenttext: Okay, that's fair. And then maybe if we think about pace of reviews coming up, both for Q4 and what you're seeing in the RFP pipeline for next year. And I guess, kind of question goes back to what you've talked about with your media agnostic strategy as well as the Facebook video measurement issue. Do you see any of these is catalyzing another round of reviews like we saw in 2015? Or would you think that the next 12 months is going to be a little less manic than what you saw 12 months prior?

headline: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
companyname: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc.
componenttextpreview: Yes, I said I didn't think 2016 was going to be as manic as 2015. And I think that was true, except for certain holding companies had particular items in review. Unfortunately, that wasn't us. And I do think the whole spectrum of transparency raises legit
componenttext: Yes, I said I didn't think 2016 was going to be as manic as 2015. And I think that was true, except for certain holding companies had particular items in review. Unfortunately, that wasn't us. And I do think the whole spectrum of transparency raises legitimate questions for clients to look at the service providers. We're doing a very strong and effective communication with our clients in terms of our transparency. Frankly, some of our clients have orders out there in terms of what we're doing. Unfortunately, we're coming through those pretty well, that's good. And I think from a tone point of view, clients will continue to look at this. Whether it gives rise to pitches and reviews, I can't say, but I would expect we'll see a fair amount of reviews coming into '17. Not, the least of which is these goals and cycles, and we're heading into the third of a third year of cycles and clients have 3-year contracts and has an order of business practice as they put a number of their businesses in review every 2 or 3 years. So I expect to see, I'll call that normal, it's not normal what it used to be, but it seems to be normal what's happening in our industry.

headline: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
companyname: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc.
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Mr. Omer Sheikh from Crdit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question is from Mr. Omer Sheikh from Crdit Suisse.

headline: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
companyname: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc.
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of questions. First, for Frank on margins. If you look at the first 9 months, it looks like most of the -- sort of improvement you see in margin comes in O&G rather than salaries. I just wonder whether you could give some commentary on wheth
componenttext: Just a couple of questions. First, for Frank on margins. If you look at the first 9 months, it looks like most of the -- sort of improvement you see in margin comes in O&G rather than salaries. I just wonder whether you could give some commentary on whether you see that sort of continuing into Q4 and maybe anything you have to say about next year and the kind of scope, the mix of margin improvement, that would be helpful. And then Michael, you called out data and analytics as being an area that you'd like to invest behind. I wonder whether you could talk about whether your preference would be for organic or inorganic investment behind that theme.

headline: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
companyname: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc.
componenttextpreview: Sure. Look, data analytics is an important product. We historically -- we've done strategic acquisitions. We see most of our growth coming organically, for example, in Cadreon, we've seen -- we've expanded it internationally. We've coordinated their offer
componenttext: Sure. Look, data analytics is an important product. We historically -- we've done strategic acquisitions. We see most of our growth coming organically, for example, in Cadreon, we've seen -- we've expanded it internationally. We've coordinated their offerings among all resources and agencies within U.S. and we will continue to do that. So I think the bulk of the growth will come organically. However, we are looking at strategic acquisitions in that space. We also are looking at a more coordinated basis in terms of our database, if you will, in terms of a DMP. And that will be a key focus for us in 2017. To make sure that all the agencies within IPG have a consistent offering and utilizing the unique capabilities we have at Mediabrands. That's -- I see that as an important growth vehicle for us. Clients are looking for. That's the area where we're seeing a lot of competitors, if you will, trying to get you have inroads in our clients. So that's where -- and I talked about investment in data analytics, and we're going to be stepping up our efforts in those parts. And frankly, if we don't have it organically, and we don't have those capabilities internally, we will look to add on. Look, with Mediabrands, we added 2 very nice agencies this past year. One in the SEO space and one in the mobile space. Those are growth vehicles for us. Mobile, clearly, it's going to be a key driver for business going forward. Our Ansible offering, we've consolidated a number of businesses with the new acquisitions to make sure that we have full integrated mobile offering across our various brands. So this is the value of a holding company across all of our networks, and we continue to focus Mediabrands as the key source of providing those unique competencies utilizing these kinds of data.

headline: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
companyname: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc.
componenttextpreview: And Omar, on the margin question, we target our agencies to deliver a margin improvement target and whether we get leverage from both major cost buckets, one major cost buckets, it's somewhere relevant us. With that said, Michael made a comment earlier on
componenttext: And Omar, on the margin question, we target our agencies to deliver a margin improvement target and whether we get leverage from both major cost buckets, one major cost buckets, it's somewhere relevant us. With that said, Michael made a comment earlier on about the importance of talents. So right now, we attribute our growth being tied to the investments we made against talent. We're constantly looking at that. So to the extent we can squeeze more out of O&G to help support those investments in talent and still meet our margin objectives, that's a good answer. But with that said, Michael mentioned 50% of our profits in the fourth quarter right, so I would imagine that our salary line is a contributor of leverage in the fourth quarter and as we move to '17 and '17 as well.

headline: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
companyname: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc.

componenttext: Our next question is from Mr. Brian Wieser from Pivotal Research.

headline: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
companyname: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc.
componenttextpreview: Some use disposition some of McCann in season the Nordic markets [indiscernible] past quarter and separately, we know the Publicis is how it's managing markets below the top 20. I was wondering sort of macro industry level -- and may be for RPG specifical
componenttext: Some use disposition some of McCann in season the Nordic markets [indiscernible] past quarter and separately, we know the Publicis is how it's managing markets below the top 20. I was wondering sort of macro industry level -- and may be for RPG specifically as well, if you think it's less necessary now than it was say, 20 and 40 years ago to have these massive extensive global networks that have sort of dominated the largest creative agency groups. And certainly wonder if you could also talk about the current ebbs and flows of centralization versus decentralization in some of agency groups. For example, seems like there's a lot of deepening of investment in Cadreon versus putting maybe more investment in some of the individual media agency brands, not that there's investment going there as well, but just curious your thoughts on how much should live with agency brand versus more centralized entities.

headline: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
companyname: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc.
componenttextpreview: You got 1.5 hours, Brian. Let me start. 10 years ago, we started open architecture, okay? And it was our belief that clients -- in a client-centric environment, that we should be focusing on the needs of the clients, not our particular silos. And when we
componenttext: You got 1.5 hours, Brian. Let me start. 10 years ago, we started open architecture, okay? And it was our belief that clients -- in a client-centric environment, that we should be focusing on the needs of the clients, not our particular silos. And when we look at open architecture, the issue is do we, in essence, mold all of our agencies together and say by the way, here's the best people and irrespective of the silo. And obviously, there were complications, there were cultural issues, there are different go-to-market strategies and frankly, that served as well in the marketplace. We don't believe that we need to restructure our entire company to make open architecture work. We've been doing open architecture for 10 years. And frankly, some of our most profitable and growing clients utilize an open architecture model. And the reason it works is because we've made it part of the DNA of our organization. People within the "silos" know that if we they don't have the capabilities within their agencies, they can raise their hand, and we can bring in an expertise that will work closely with them on a collaborative basis and meet the needs of our clients. You don't need to restructure the entire company to do that. And the reason we're comfortable with that is we hold our agencies responsible for collaborative work. So when we do compensation and incentive compensation, we look at the degree of open architecture and collaboration. And on many of the engagements, there are multiple agencies serving one client, and they don't have to worry about whose silo they belong to because frankly, we do that. We work closely with agencies, and we determine what the proper allocation. Clients shouldn't be involved in it. We think that's a better way of doing this because when you have one single purpose agency doing this, we have a number of those, but most of the time, when you have a single-purpose agency, it's harder to recruit talent, it's harder to keep talent, it's harder to get a sustainability of the quality of the people within those agencies. And open architecture is serving us very well. We get the highest grades of our reviews when we have open architecture models because the clients realize that we're putting them first. And by the way, our definition of open architecture includes third party providers. So if our client come to us and say, we like you to work with XYZ in addition to your resources, sometimes we work better with third parties unfortunately than our own. But that's part of the model. If you collaborated everyone and put them all into 1 silo, you will never get that, okay? So I think the notion of providing all the resources IPG has to a client is the correct one, which is why frankly, we started it 10 years ago. But I don't believe you have to restructure the company to do that. You lose a lot of the culture, you lose a lot of the accountability, and you lose the focus that our core agencies have within those particular agencies.

headline: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
companyname: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc.
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the bigger question getting out is the outside of the top the largest markets that was the restructuring aspect what Publicis has been doing, I'm curious. I guess, I'm wondering if you're seeing something similar with some of the dispositions
componenttext: Yes, I think the bigger question getting out is the outside of the top the largest markets that was the restructuring aspect what Publicis has been doing, I'm curious. I guess, I'm wondering if you're seeing something similar with some of the dispositions of McCann. In other words, do you need to have expand to 60 country markets in this role going forward?

headline: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
companyname: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc.
componenttextpreview: Of course. We started -- the first year we came, we [indiscernible] 50 agencies all over the world. I said, we got rid of [indiscernible].  We don't need agencies in those markets. Because the world doesn't operate that way anymore. So yes, we constantly
componenttext: Of course. We started -- the first year we came, we [indiscernible] 50 agencies all over the world. I said, we got rid of [indiscernible].  We don't need agencies in those markets. Because the world doesn't operate that way anymore. So yes, we constantly looking at that and ensure that this positions that we've made are consistent. We're getting rid of nonproducing agencies that don't cost, that are costing us money and aren't getting any value. So that's what we've been doing. On the question of Cadreon and Mediabrands and whether we're decentralizing, it doesn't make sense to invest all of that money in one particular offering and not have it available for all the other agencies. When I first came to this business, I used to walk around, travel to our different agencies, and they were all real out what they believe is best-in-class offerings and particular, on the media side. And we we're spending a lot of money and a lot of things that we didn't have to duplicate if everyone be able to raise their hand and work closely with the competencies for example Mediabrands, whether the UM, initiative or Mediabrands as the holding company, if you will, of media. And I think that's the right way to do it. And we've done that terrific job on that. For example, if you look at MullenLowe and Mediabrands and Mediahub at MullenLowe working with Mediabrands on the Western Union pitch. I mean, that was a great example of competencies within an agency as well as tapping into particular resources we have in Mediabrands. The same thing is Harley-Davidson. The same thing in all of our open architecture wins. So I think that is the most efficient way to use our expertise and the most efficient way to meet the needs of our clients. And more of our agencies are realizing that they can do it that way, they get a better offering, and it's much more efficient and clients realize that they're looking out on their behalf instead of their own silo. Rather than that, I don't feel strongly about it, Brian.

headline: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
companyname: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc.
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Mr. Barry Lucas from Gabelli & Company.
componenttext: Our next question is from Mr. Barry Lucas from Gabelli & Company.

headline: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
companyname: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc.
componenttextpreview: Frank, I don't want to beat this margin question to death, but your comment that you expect leverage in the fourth quarter coming out of salary line. So my suspicion, strong suspicion is given the delay in onboarding some of the new business and the likel
componenttext: Frank, I don't want to beat this margin question to death, but your comment that you expect leverage in the fourth quarter coming out of salary line. So my suspicion, strong suspicion is given the delay in onboarding some of the new business and the likelihood that you've had people in place to serve those accounts ahead of the business coming in. Now, the revenue is coming and that would be one of those conservative factors to improvement in that area?

headline: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
companyname: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc.
componenttextpreview: Yes, we look very closely at sequential progression of our salary line, whether that be in headcount, whether that be in other components. And if you look from first quarter, second quarter or third quarter, it's clear our operators are managing that quit
componenttext: Yes, we look very closely at sequential progression of our salary line, whether that be in headcount, whether that be in other components. And if you look from first quarter, second quarter or third quarter, it's clear our operators are managing that quite efficiently. As you pointed out, the fourth quarter is our largest revenue and profit quarter. So do we expect is that revenue starts to ramp up that we're hiring massive heads? We don't. So we should get appropriate leverage through the salary line in the fourth quarter. Again, we take a lot of comfort in -- manage our operationability to manage sequential headcount progression and they're doing a very good job.

headline: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
companyname: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc.
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me just add one other point  to that, Barry. New clients tend to have less margin than more mature clients, and that's a fact in our business. So what I'm tempering a little bit the expectation frankly, that as we onboard all those new business t
componenttext: Yes, let me just add one other point  to that, Barry. New clients tend to have less margin than more mature clients, and that's a fact in our business. So what I'm tempering a little bit the expectation frankly, that as we onboard all those new business that we have, it's coming in very high margins and the margin number of expectations should be a lot higher than frankly, as this business matures as we go through it. That said, we do have some revenue coming into the fourth quarter that we've already incurred a significant amount of expenses. And obviously, that revenue comes with a higher margin. So this is not an exact science. The timing of how we get our revenue and how our expenses is fluid, if you will, because we have to manage to make sure we have the right people onboarding new business, as Frank said, but we also have the realize that expectations of new clients takes a period of time for it to mature. It just doesn't happen overnight, which is why even when we started the year everyone said, why are you being so conservative in terms of your organic growth and margin. And the answer to that is, staffing and onboarding new clients and macroeconomic all come into play at onetime.  It's a tricky thing to model, and that's why we like to look at this on a full year basis as opposed to quarter-to-quarter. So we manage it as best as we can, but if 50% of our [indiscernible] comes into the fourth quarter, we can't with a high degree of accuracy tell exactly where that's going to come.

headline: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
companyname: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc.
componenttextpreview: Our final question is from Mr. Dan Salmon from BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our final question is from Mr. Dan Salmon from BMO Capital Markets.

headline: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
companyname: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc.
componenttextpreview: Michael, in your prepared remarks on the individual units for FCB, you highlighted their shopper marketing division, in particular, for strength. My question was on shopper marketing more broadly across IPG as it's an area that one of your peers have stat
componenttext: Michael, in your prepared remarks on the individual units for FCB, you highlighted their shopper marketing division, in particular, for strength. My question was on shopper marketing more broadly across IPG as it's an area that one of your peers have stated us a bit of a challenging one recently. It sounds like it's a bit of more positive story for you. Could you maybe remind us the size of that discipline across all IPG, your short and near-term views on it? And in particular maybe the difference between how it performs domestically in emerging markets and maybe how it's evolving towards digital. And then one other just high-level question, you also commented on the continued convergence of the consultants and systems integrators. Just anything that you're seeing that's changing there, in particular, seeing some of those competitors may be starting to look at creative our media as opposed to sort of strategy and technology work, that would be great.

headline: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
companyname: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc.
componenttextpreview: Yes, those are 2 great questions. Shopper marketing, it's important to FCB have a great competency in it. I would say if not big overall, I wouldn't say it's a major part of our business at IPG as a whole. That said, your opportunities for those agencies
componenttext: Yes, those are 2 great questions. Shopper marketing, it's important to FCB have a great competency in it. I would say if not big overall, I wouldn't say it's a major part of our business at IPG as a whole. That said, your opportunities for those agencies that offer it in a very effective basis, and we will continue to invest behind it when we see opportunities. But I wouldn't call it out as one of the major growth vehicles around the world, if you will. But it is very important to FCB, and they do a great job at it. In fact, that's one of the agencies we pull out when we have our piece that call for shopper marketing expertise because they do it so well. The more broader question on the convergence is really how we had to look at the transformation of our industry. I do believe we are seeing new competitors entering our business, and they are bringing with them CRM expertise. They're basically system integrators. And because they're already in our clients, they view it as an opportunity to bring in CRM expertise as well as creative, which is another reason why I think when we compete against those, the fact that we have standalone agencies with strong creative talent, it's very hard for these other parties to compete against whether McCann or an FCB or MullenLowe or our independent agencies the firepower we can bring in for creative work. There's no way that these new competitors if, if you will, come compete with that. And the results showed that. Even though these outliers, they were coming into our business are trying to get there, I think if you look across all the holding companies, we've been pretty successful when it comes to those integrated offerings that we provide versus what they're providing. That said, we had to watch it very carefully. And clearly, they're going to be coming out pretty strongly, so we have to be well suited. And I believe, the open architecture integrated offering is a very compelling argument against them trying to get into our business.
